Quartetto Italiano scores
By J.D. CONSIDINE
The Quartetto Italiano, one of
Europe's finest chamber
ensembles, appeared at Shriver
Hall Saturday in a concert which
amply illustrated both their
technical facility as well as their
stylistic predilictions.
Having played together for
more than thirty years, the
amount of rapport the Quartetto
Italiano has developed is
understandably remarkable. With
little in the way of noticible
signals, the quartet manages to
keep an uncanny sense of
phrasing, tempo, and dynamics.
Melodic lines pass from viola to
first violin with such deftness
that one almost assumes that the
sound came from one
instrument. Ensemble blending is
so precise that it becomes
difficult to place the voices in a
chord with the instruments
producing the sound.
However admirable this may
be technically, one might be
tempted to question the validity
of such a sound when applied to
the works of all composers.
Surely, just as two different
composers will employ different
style's, the tone employed by an
ensemble playing those works
should register that difference.
Regrettably in Saturday's
concert, this was not always the
case.

CPS shorts
(CPS)--Some pedple never give
up. Blistered by the election
results, Jim Johnson, a University
of Nebraska student, has founded
an anti-Carter/Mondale group in
Lincoln, Nebraska. Johnson, a
registered Republican, explained
that his organization is
reactionary, not radical.
Shortly after the Carter's
victory, Johnson placed an ad in
the Daily Nebraskan soliciting
cohorts for the group, which will
examine and criticize the
Democratic platform of Carter
and Mondale. Johnson has been
barraged by phone calls ever
since, though no one has left a
last name.
"My greatest concern," said
Johnson, "is that the Democratic
platform tends to lean towards
socialism. I don't want to see
socialism in my lifetime, so
hopefully this organization can
look into this and other issues
and see what Carter plans to do."
Johnson hopes that the group
will expand soon to other points
in Nebraska and then nationwide.
"This is very exciting to me," he
commented, "because it's my
first real experience in politics."

chaos of students fighting for the
right to be represented on their
college governing boards?
Well, a new government study,
titled "Students and Collective
Bargaining," has come out with
the suprising conclusion that
students who are currently on
the boards of directors of their

colleges tend to have a
pro-management bias.

In international skullduggery, dissidents lose
By K.E.T.
Not a day has gone by in the
past several months that the
major news publications haven't
run a story on the harrassment of
dissidents in the East European
countries or the Soviet Union.
The United States, the land
where human rights and freedom
are guarded with unequaled zeal,
must take up the case of these
unfortunate souls to assure full
Soviet conformity to the Helsinki
Accords of August 1975. But
numerous problems arise
concerning the treatment of
dissidents in relation to this
agreement, foremost among them
is the omission of any sort of
interpretive or judicial body
established to ponder the fine
meanings of such intangibles as
'human rights' or 'greater
freedom of movement.'
Overlooking the lack of such a
body, questions naturally arise
concerning the direction and
Ultimate effectiveness of the
United States' policy towards
dissent in these Comrrunist
countries.
The Administration's position,
as expressed by Secretary of
State Cyrus Vance, is indefinite
at best on this subject: "We will
not comment on each and every
issue, but we will from time to
time comment when we see a
threat to human rights when we
believe it constructive to do so."
Ostensibly, 'comment' is seen as
a constructive means of fighting
for human rights in the Soviet
Union. What is more likely is that

commentary as an irritant, an

Fundamentally, U.S.—Soviet

and even to extend this right to
direct criticism of the

By STEVE BALOG
In response to a growing
demand for campus parking
Space by commutingstudents, the
Homewood Campus Traffic and
Parking Committee has
implemented several remedial
actions. The Committee,
composed of faculty, staff and
students, is charged with making
recommendations regarding
Parking and traffic regulations
for the Homewood campus.
In addition to the commuter
Problem, the Committee has had
to deal with complaints by
residents of Charles Village
(specifically, residents of the
Homewood and Bradford
apartment buildings) of excessive
use of street spaces by Hopkins
students. The Committee and the

Student Council believe that
these students, as rent-paying
residents themselves, are entitled
to whatever space is available in
the community. The off-campus
Homewood Garage, owned by
the University and offering
lowered rates, was seen as an
immediate solution to this
problem. It is, however, already
losing money.
The undergraduate member of
the Committee, Paula Canelos,
works with a graduate
representative overseeing the
interests of all commuting
students. Canelos described an
ongoing effort, begun three
weeks ago, to encourage the
formation of carpools by
commuting students. So far, 25
people (6 more since spring

registration), have formed such
arrangements. All parties
interested in setting up a carpool
should already possess or qualify
for JHU parking permits. The
Office of Plant Planning and
Operations in Room 114,
Garland Hall, is still accepting
carpool applications which were
distributed at registration.
The application require a
listing of at least three
narticipants. Canelos stressed the
fact that carpoolers have received
preferential parking spaces. Thus
far, some metered spaces east of
Garland Hall have been assigned.
In the future, spaces behind
Shriver Hall will be assigned to
commuters who choose to pool.
A special permit is given to each
group that participates in the

program and is transferable to
each of the cars designated for
carpool use in the application.
"One out of every three
vehicles are compact cars"
Canelos said another measure
instituted by the committee, for
commuters unable to take part in
the car pool plan, is a
reorganization of parking spaces.
She estimated one out of three
vehicles used by faculty and
students (Type I and II JHU
parking permits) are compact
cars, as defined by the Office of
Plant Operations guidelines.
American compacts such as
Javelins, Pintos, Vegas, or Jeeps
and all foreign models except
Citroen, Jaguar, Mercedes-Benz,

Comment' is not going to bring a
halt to repression any more than
name-calling succeeds in
discouraging undesirable
behavior. (We can huff and we
can puff, but we're just not going
to be able to blow their house
down.) The line of action that
hes, seem to hold some promise
is Dr. Kissinger's recently
rejected 'linkage' policy, which
links matters of policy to trade.
This tactic, however, has often
caused even more heated
relations between our two
countries. It is true that the
Soviet leadership understands the
language of technological trade,
for it is in this field that the
Soviet most certainly needs
assistance. But if the
manufacturers of advanced
computer and electronic
equipment continue to meet the
Soviet demand (with the tacit
approval of the current
Administration), we can never
expect to make gains in our
'commitment to assuring human
rights.' Unfortunately, the
cessation of trade in
technological goods is not likely
to be adopted by the new
administration. Although .the
ideological war wages, the
profitable stream of commerce
must continue. Our
'commitment' to the human
rights of certain segments of the
world's populations is not fooling
anyone, They are getting what
they want (the advanced
technology) and we are getting
what we want (the $). Too bad
that the dissidents are the only
ones that lose

Volkswagen buses and Volvo,
model 1800 qualify. Sometime
this week or next, the lot directly
south of Garland Hall will be
restriped for compact cars. This
change should increase lot
capacity by 14 per cent, she said.
A number of other solutions
to the commuter parking crunch
have been proposed by the
Committee. The most extreme
alternative, building a multi-level
garage on campus, is neither
serious nor even feasible, since
parking fees would have to be
instituted to pay for its
construction. A suitable location
for such a garage would also have
to be found. However, Canelos
said a survey would be taken in
the near future for a reaction to
this idea.

promises
The Carter administration, attempting to retain the
broadbased coalition of moderates and liberals, threatens to
isolate some of its most volatile supporters: administrators,
professors and university students. Attempting to show
fiscal restraint, the new administration plans to cut back its
appropriations on such essential programs as National
Direct Student Loans, Work-Study, Opportunity and
Supplemental Opportunity Grants for needy students.
Although Carter promised to execute the Democratic
platform's pledge "to fund the campus - based student aid
programs," his present position shows gross neglect to the
realities of high priced collegiate education.
But Carter still has time to uphold his "I will never lie to
the American people." Such fiscal restraint is laudable, but
could better be shown in other areas, like the .overstocking
of federal employees in the postal system and defense
department. If Carter clings to his present plan, higher
education lobbiests will be put to the test of influencing
Congress to increase the President's budget in this vital
area.

Party time at the Hop?
By STRETCH HOGAN
"What's a nine letter word for
'fun?'"
"Frat party!" I shot back at
the missis hunched over the
Times crossword puzzle, "got
any other 'easy ones' for me,
sugar?"
"Say, isn't it about time......
"Yes, honeybunch, fraternity
rush begins this week and lasts
through the rest of the month.
And it's about time. The social
life around here has been pretty
gruesome lately, and I'm afraid
the natives are getting restless."
Indeed, as I studied her sleek
flank stretched along the couch, I
remembered when I was a
restless, callow sophomore and
scampered from fraternity to
fraternity in search of a few
-cheap thrills. Making the rounds,
you feel like a Skid Row bum
staggering on the hovel-lined
streets south and east of campus,
or a prep school flunkie
stumbling before the ante-bellum
mansions to the north. What
physical state you're in never
seems to matter; usually you're
with a few cronies and after
downing a few at the last stop,
chances are you're all
rhythmatically snapping your
fingers trying to act like the Jets
on their way to a rumble with
the Sharks. The beer flows fast
and free and combined with the
general smoky and noisy
atmosphere, the buzz, as they
say, comes faster and louder. It
sets the mood for a night of
raucous Rabelaisian rascality

that's likely to become the
highlight of the social season here
at the Hop.
Drinking and comraderie are
not the only reasons to go
party-hopping...The first time I
ever saw the missis she was sitting
alluringly among the cushions of
an ostermoor at DU, her legs
crossed as an hex for those with
less than Quaker thoughts. To be
perfectly and honestly

chauvanistic, the pleasures of the
flesh (or a good piece of bottom
land, as Rodney Dangerfield
would have it) loom large in the
minds of all. You always have the
feeling that a pair of beady little
eyes are following your path
through the crowd to the bar, as
if under the scrutiny of a
marksman through his sight. The
cramped space does not subtract
from the forced intimacy, and
the lack of light only accentuates

the romantic mood. The music
drives your blood into a frenzy
and you have an irresponsible
urge to frug with the person
nearest you. This feeling of being
the center of an overwhelming
sensual experience is enough to
last you through the rest of the
winter until lacrosse season
begins.
A lot of people have
bad-mouthed fraternities in the
past. From experience, I know
many of these nay-sayers have
been blackballed from various
frats; others have had terrible
experiences at frat parties which
have left them with a bizarre
look in their eyes, Rathskellar
groupies who slowly guzzle their
brew waiting for something to
happen. But, normal people seem
to enjoy frat parties, bravely
entering the bowels of the
fraternity houses, eager to find
their 'way to the bar and dance
floor and the ersatz paradise that
surely waits there. There has to
be an outlet from the frustrations
of academic pressures; in other
words, don't let the GPA
bastards grind you down.
The actual rush process begins
early this week when the
brothers canvass the dorms,
which only proves the old adage
that frats rush in where angels
fear to tread. Do not be afraid to
let these hucksters into your
room? Listen to what they say
and seriously consider the
possibility of joining a fraternity.
It may be the biggest decision
you make in your freshman year.

Sugar Ray Leonard
shown off
at civic center
By DEBI KIBLER
A freebie was being offered by
the Baltimore Civic Center! Sugar
Ray Leonard, Olympic gold
medalist in middleweight boxing,
was making an appearance in
Charm City to fight on Feb. 5.
The City of Baltimore, as
promoter, attempted to attract
people to the main event by
making Sugar Ray's training
sessions free and open to the
Public. From noon until 2 p.m.
every day before the fight, the
Public could watch Sugar Ray
Work out and possibly meet him.
I have never been within sight of
an actual boxing ring, let alone a
boxer, so after a little prompting
I decided to go downtown and
check out this new wonderboy.
I arrived at the Civic Center
and after winding through its
grimy bowels, came to the
garage, which had been converted
into a training area. The City had
apparently gone to great lengths
to make this extra attraction
appealing. There were rows of
folding chairs for the spectators
on three sides of the ring and a
hot dog stand. About two
hundred people were already
there; women, children,
.executives, bums, and novices
like myself.
Sugar Ray and his sparring
Partner, his cousin Odell
Leonard, were in the ring
receiving last minute instructions
from a trainer. Both Leonards
were attired in personalized
orange Civic Center T-shirts.
Sugar Ray and Odell had their
faces greased under the
Protective helmets, so that
misplaced punches could do little

or no harm. Their training gloves
weighed 16 ounces apiece, a
half-pound heavier than the
gloves Sugar Ray would use
against Luis "The Bull" Vega.
The training gloves are heavier,
yet protective, like big pillows on
the fighters' hands. Sugar Ray
and Odell would spar for five
3-minute rounds. An announcer
was also present, who advised tbe
spectators between rounds to
buy their tickets, which cost up
to twenty bucks a seat.
I don't think I ever realized it
before, but a fighter's personality
comes through when he fights.
Odell Leonard, built like a small
George Foreman, was a clown in
the ring. He was dancing around
Sugar Ray and making amusing
gestures to the audience. Odell
was definitely heavier than his
cousin, though shorter, and his the training rounds, I could teL
fighting skills were considerably that Sugar Ray has great
less developed than those of his potential He seemed loose, and

showed the determination that the crowd was treated to the fine
won him the gold medal in form that won Sugar Ray
Montreal. He is not, however, an recognition in the Olympics.

As a sparring partner, Odell was loudly after every round and to

muttering instructions to Odell such as "shake 'im up", "make
and encouragement to Sugar Ray 'im sweat", and "put 'er in
throughout each round. Even in automatic, Odell", were flying

through the air. A few hecklers
were present, but in general the
crowd was jovial and any
heckling was ignored.
After the sparring was over,
Sugar Ray took time to sign
autographs and shake hands. He
was sincere in meeting and
talking to his admirers, which
undoubtedly accounts for his
great popularity. It was with
some difficulty that he made his
way to the heavy punching bag:
people especially youngsters.
were crowding around him. Sugar
Ray showed the same dynamic
style on the bag as he did in the
ring. Most of the crowd
remained, and gathered around
to watch. He attacked the bag for
about fifteen minutes and believe
me, he's no slouch. It was
extremely difficult not to be
impressed by his strength. While
Sugar Ray was punching his heart
out,Odell was skipping rope.
That may sound easy to some of
you, but it actually takes months
to learn to do it correctly,
involving precise timing and lots
of endurance. The only way
Floyd Patterson could learn to
do it was by jumping off the
boxing ring and bring the rope
over his head and under his feet
before he hit the floor. Sugar
Ray finished punching the bag
and after another session of
public relations, began skipping
rope. With this the training
session was ended.
The City of Baltimore is to be
congratulated for its efforts in
promoting Sugar Ray's fight. The
training session was well
organized; children and adults
were not discouraged from
climbing into the ring. Sugar Ray
was a perfect gentleman and the
trainers also took time to discuss
boxing with interested
spectators. Due to Baltimore's
support of Sugar Ray, I think his
career has been given a major
boost. From the appeal of a
freebie, more potential admierers
and supporters were exposed to
Sugar Ray than would have been
possible.
Since I watched Sugar Ray
train, he has had a very successful
bout (unanimous decision) with
Vega. The crowd was estimated
at over 9,000 people, outdoing

Muhammad Ali, who attracted
6,100 people to a Civic Center
exhibition fight in 1972. Sugar
Ray was very appreciative about
the attention he's received from
the City and in an interview on
Feb. 7 said, "Baltimore is the
home of Sugar Ray Leonard."
Manager Angelo Dundee alsc
must have been suitably
impressed, for he claims to have
Sugar Ray back for a fight in
Baltimore on April 2.
Does this interest in Sugar Ray
Leonard indicate a change in the
sport of boxing? In the past few
years, boxing has declined in
popularity, despite the attempts
of Ali and others to keep it in the
news. One of the reasons for the
rekindling of boxing may have
been the 1976 Olympics, where
the United States team won
about half the gold medals in
boxing. Sugar Ray was one of the
gold medalists and a favorite of
Howard Cosell. The sportscasters
agreed that of all the boxers at
Montreal, Sugar Ray had the best
chance to make it as a
professional. After he won the
gold medal, however, Sugar Ray
claimed he would not fight
professionally. Some thought he
made this statement because of a
problem with swelling hands.
Sugar Ray was questioned about
this in an interview before his
Civic Center fight and said that
iiis hands were in great shape. So
it seems that, regardless of his
statement at Montreal, Sugar Ray
is on his way to becoming a
successful pro boxer. It is a
well-known fact, however, that in
the boxing profession, the
heavyweights gather all the glory
and publicity. This near-axiom
might make Sugar Ray's path to
greater reknown a little
mcertain. His career is being
watched nationally, possibly
because aficionados feel he's the
one who can break the
heavyweight stranglehold on
boxing.
April 2
For those of you who missed
Sugar Ray, try to see him when
he returns April 2. Besides being
a native of Maryland, he's a fine
young athlete. Take it from a
novice boxing fan, you won't be
disappointed.

Social Security will have a limited number of positions
available this summer for qualified students. Hopkins may
only nominate three students in each category listed below.
Category No. 1, GS-4 level positions in this category are
available to students entering their senior year in the fall of
1977, who will have completed their junior year by June,
1977. Qualifying majors for these positions are liberal arts,
mathematics, statistics and computer science. All positions
are located at SSA Headquarters in Baltimore, Md.

are available to students who will have will have completed
all requirements for a bachelor's degree by June, 1977, and
who have applied for, or are currently enrolled in one of the
following graduate programs--mathematics, statistics,
computer science, economics or one of the social sciences.
Positions are located in Baltimore, Maryland and Washington,
DC.
In addition, applicants must meet the following general
requirements: (a) be American citizens; (b) be bona-fide
cotlege students who will be returning to school in the fall;
and (c) rank in the upper one-third of their graduate class for
Category No. 2. Sons and daughters of Department of
Health, Education, and Welfare employees are not eligible for
the program. Positions are not available for students majoring
in chemistry, engineering, physics, biology.
All interested students must see Sharon Baughan, Student
Employment Officer. 125A Garland Hall before February 28,
1977.

By ANDREW COHEN
The Blue Jay men's varsity
basketball team dropped into a
second place tie with Washington
College as they were completely
outplayed by the Widener
Pioneers Saturday night in
Chester, Pennsylvania, 62-47.
The game was so lopsided, in
fact, that if it hadn't been for
John Finston's game leading 26
points, the Jays could have gone
home at the end of the first half.
During the first 8 minutes,
however, the Blue Jays were very
much in the game. The Jays
controlled the opening tip, but
failed to connect when Dan
Kopcza's short turnaround jump
shot was blocked by 6'6"
forward Mark Tucker of Widener.
The Pioneers turned the
defensive gem into an offensive
surge capped off with a driving
layup from guard Mark Donahue,
who led the balanced scoring
attack for Widener with 19
points. Finston quickly tied the
game at 2 by pumping in a 25
foot jump shot from the top of
the foul circle.
Moments later, the Jays took
the lead when Andy Scheinfeld
hit a beautiful turn around jump
shot. After the score was tied,
Scheinfeld again put the Jays up
by driving past two Widener
defenders and scopping the ball
in. But two Widener buckets
dropped in by Donahue put the
Pioneers in the lead to stay 8-6.

The Jays hung close to the
Pioneers with two jump shots
from Randy Lovallo and two
foul shots sunk by Dean Uhler.
Widener then went on a scoring
binge, outscoring the Jays 8-2 in
the next three minutes. The Jays
went dry in the remaining 9
minutes of the first half,
mustering only two field goals
from Finston and Lovallo.
Costly turnovers and failure to
gain the offensive rebound
spelled the difference for the
Jays as they ended the first half
trailing 29-18. The Blue Jays shot
a poor 8-21 or 38% from the
floor while the Pioneers hit 13 of
31 or 47% of their shots. In
addition, the Jays were unable to
pull down one offensive rebound
in the first half.
The second half offered no
consolation to the visiting team
as the Pioneers ran the score to
34-18 before the Jays could
answer with a bucket from
Finston. The Widener team took
the opening tip and converted an
easy layup. Seconds later,
pioneer senior Jim Fitzpatrick
took a pinpoint pass from 6'6"
senior Dennis James and drove to
the hoop dropping in the shot. In
the process he was fouled,
allowing him to complete a three
point play.
An interesting call by the
referee prevented Widener from
taking an eighteen point lead.
Donahue led a Pioneer three on

one drive to the bucket and the
Widener guard eventually shot a
running layup. The ball bounced
around the rim for a while before
the Pioneer center (James)leaped
up and grabbed the ball, slammed
it into the hoop, and hung on the
rim. Hanging on the rim
constitutes a technical foul in
NCAA play. The referee also
called offensive goal tending,
explaining that the ball was
above the imaginery plane of the
basket when James took hold of
it. Unfortunately for the Jays,
technical free throw shooter
Kevin Kabat missed the shot.
The Pioneers continued to
pump the ball through the net,
but Finston seemed to answer
with his baseline jump shots
every time. At 12:43 of the
second half, guard Lovallo
sprained his ankle in the process
of attempting to block a shot.
The valuable 6'1" playmaker
took a flying leap at a Widener
offensive player and came up
limping. He was quickly replaced
with Duey Levine by Coach
Rupert.
"Randy is definitely going to
miss Monday and Wednesday
nights' games," commented
Coach Rupert. "Luckily the
x-rays taken came out negative."
The Blue Jays now stand at
5-3 in their league, tied with
Washington College. The next
two league games against
Haver ford College and

The members of the Blue Jay
men's varsity swimming team

from—they've gotten into the
habit of beating everyone.
On February 5th, JHU racked
up its fifth win in seven decision

defeated American University
69-43. Hopkins raised its dual
meet record to 9-2 on February
12th when it stomped perennial
Division III powerhouse
Allegheny College, 72-41.
The competition against
American was effectively over
after the first three events. By
that time, JHU had built up a
commanding 20-5 lead that was
never seriously threatened.
This advantage had been
created through successive
victories in the 400-yard medley
relay, the 1000-yard freestyle
and the 200-yard freestyle.
Following an American win in
the 50-yard freestyle, the Jays
grabbed both first and second in
the 200-yard individual medley
and the 1-meter diving to take a
40-11 lead.

(CPS)--Some pedple never give
up. Blistered by the election
results, Jim Johnson, a University
of Nebraska student, has founded
an anti-Carter/Mondale group in
Lincoln, Nebraska. Johnson, a
registered Republican, explained
that his organization is
reactionary, not radical.
Shortly after the Carter's
victory, Johnson placed an ad in
the Daily Nebraskan soliciting
cohorts for the group, which will
examine and criticize the
Democratic platform of Carter
and Mondale. Johnson has been
barraged by phone calls ever
since, though no one has left a
last name.
"My greatest concern," said
Johnson, "is that the Democratic
platform tends to lean towards
socialism. I don't want to see
socialism in my lifetime, so
hopefully this organization can
look into this and other issues
and see what Carter plans to do."
Johnson hopes that the group
will expand soon to other points
in Nebraska and then nationwide.
"This is very exciting to me," he
commented, "because it's my
first real experience in politics."

By STEVE BALOG
In response to a growing
demand for campus parking
Space by commutingstudents, the
Homewood Campus Traffic and
Parking Committee has
implemented several remedial
actions. The Committee,
composed of faculty, staff and
students, is charged with making
recommendations regarding
Parking and traffic regulations
for the Homewood campus.
In addition to the commuter
Problem, the Committee has had
to deal with complaints by
residents of Charles Village
(specifically, residents of the
Homewood and Bradford
apartment buildings) of excessive
use of street spaces by Hopkins
students. The Committee and the

Student Council believe that
these students, as rent-paying
residents themselves, are entitled
to whatever space is available in
the community. The off-campus
Homewood Garage, owned by
the University and offering
lowered rates, was seen as an
immediate solution to this
problem. It is, however, already
losing money.
The undergraduate member of
the Committee, Paula Canelos,
works with a graduate
representative overseeing the
interests of all commuting
students. Canelos described an
ongoing effort, begun three
weeks ago, to encourage the
formation of carpools by
commuting students. So far, 25
people (6 more since spring

registration), have formed such
arrangements. All parties
interested in setting up a carpool
should already possess or qualify
for JHU parking permits. The
Office of Plant Planning and
Operations in Room 114,
Garland Hall, is still accepting
carpool applications which were
distributed at registration.
The application require a
listing of at least three
narticipants. Canelos stressed the
fact that carpoolers have received
preferential parking spaces. Thus
far, some metered spaces east of
Garland Hall have been assigned.
In the future, spaces behind
Shriver Hall will be assigned to
commuters who choose to pool.
A special permit is given to each
group that participates in the

program and is transferable to
each of the cars designated for
carpool use in the application.
"One out of every three
vehicles are compact cars"
Canelos said another measure
instituted by the committee, for
commuters unable to take part in
the car pool plan, is a
reorganization of parking spaces.
She estimated one out of three
vehicles used by faculty and
students (Type I and II JHU
parking permits) are compact
cars, as defined by the Office of
Plant Operations guidelines.
American compacts such as
Javelins, Pintos, Vegas, or Jeeps
and all foreign models except
Citroen, Jaguar, Mercedes-Benz,

behavior. (We can huff and we

is Dr. Kissinger's recently

This tactic, however, has often

The Carter administration, attempting to retain the
broadbased coalition of moderates and liberals, threatens to
isolate some of its most volatile supporters: administrators,
professors and university students. Attempting to show
fiscal restraint, the new administration plans to cut back its
appropriations on such essential programs as National
Direct Student Loans, Work-Study, Opportunity and
Supplemental Opportunity Grants for needy students.
Although Carter promised to execute the Democratic
platform's pledge "to fund the campus - based student aid
programs," his present position shows gross neglect to the
realities of high priced collegiate education.
But Carter still has time to uphold his "I will never lie to
the American people." Such fiscal restraint is laudable, but
could better be shown in other areas, like the .overstocking
of federal employees in the postal system and defense
department. If Carter clings to his present plan, higher
education lobbiests will be put to the test of influencing
Congress to increase the President's budget in this vital
area.

Party time at the Hop?
By STRETCH HOGAN
"What's a nine letter word for
'fun?'"
"Frat party!" I shot back at
the missis hunched over the
Times crossword puzzle, "got
any other 'easy ones' for me,
sugar?"
"Say, isn't it about time......
"Yes, honeybunch, fraternity
rush begins this week and lasts
through the rest of the month.
And it's about time. The social
life around here has been pretty
gruesome lately, and I'm afraid
the natives are getting restless."
Indeed, as I studied her sleek
flank stretched along the couch, I
remembered when I was a
restless, callow sophomore and
scampered from fraternity to
fraternity in search of a few
-cheap thrills. Making the rounds,
you feel like a Skid Row bum
staggering on the hovel-lined
streets south and east of campus,
or a prep school flunkie
stumbling before the ante-bellum
mansions to the north. What
physical state you're in never
seems to matter; usually you're
with a few cronies and after
downing a few at the last stop,
chances are you're all
rhythmatically snapping your
fingers trying to act like the Jets
on their way to a rumble with
the Sharks. The beer flows fast
and free and combined with the
general smoky and noisy
atmosphere, the buzz, as they
say, comes faster and louder. It
sets the mood for a night of
raucous Rabelaisian rascality

that's likely to become the
highlight of the social season here
at the Hop.
Drinking and comraderie are
not the only reasons to go
party-hopping...The first time I
ever saw the missis she was sitting
alluringly among the cushions of
an ostermoor at DU, her legs
crossed as an hex for those with
less than Quaker thoughts. To be
perfectly and honestly

chauvanistic, the pleasures of the
flesh (or a good piece of bottom
land, as Rodney Dangerfield
would have it) loom large in the
minds of all. You always have the
feeling that a pair of beady little
eyes are following your path
through the crowd to the bar, as
if under the scrutiny of a
marksman through his sight. The
cramped space does not subtract
from the forced intimacy, and
the lack of light only accentuates

the romantic mood. The music
drives your blood into a frenzy
and you have an irresponsible
urge to frug with the person
nearest you. This feeling of being
the center of an overwhelming
sensual experience is enough to
last you through the rest of the
winter until lacrosse season
begins.
A lot of people have
bad-mouthed fraternities in the
past. From experience, I know
many of these nay-sayers have
been blackballed from various
frats; others have had terrible
experiences at frat parties which
have left them with a bizarre
look in their eyes, Rathskellar
groupies who slowly guzzle their
brew waiting for something to
happen. But, normal people seem
to enjoy frat parties, bravely
entering the bowels of the
fraternity houses, eager to find
their 'way to the bar and dance
floor and the ersatz paradise that
surely waits there. There has to
be an outlet from the frustrations
of academic pressures; in other
words, don't let the GPA
bastards grind you down.
The actual rush process begins
early this week when the
brothers canvass the dorms,
which only proves the old adage
that frats rush in where angels
fear to tread. Do not be afraid to
let these hucksters into your
room? Listen to what they say
and seriously consider the
possibility of joining a fraternity.
It may be the biggest decision
you make in your freshman year.

at civic center
By DEBI KIBLER
A freebie was being offered by
the Baltimore Civic Center! Sugar
Ray Leonard, Olympic gold
medalist in middleweight boxing,
was making an appearance in
Charm City to fight on Feb. 5.
The City of Baltimore, as
promoter, attempted to attract
people to the main event by
making Sugar Ray's training
sessions free and open to the
Public. From noon until 2 p.m.
every day before the fight, the
Public could watch Sugar Ray
Work out and possibly meet him.
I have never been within sight of
an actual boxing ring, let alone a
boxer, so after a little prompting
I decided to go downtown and
check out this new wonderboy.
I arrived at the Civic Center
and after winding through its
grimy bowels, came to the
garage, which had been converted
into a training area. The City had
apparently gone to great lengths
to make this extra attraction
appealing. There were rows of
folding chairs for the spectators
on three sides of the ring and a
hot dog stand. About two
hundred people were already
there; women, children,
.executives, bums, and novices
like myself.
Sugar Ray and his sparring
Partner, his cousin Odell
Leonard, were in the ring
receiving last minute instructions
from a trainer. Both Leonards
were attired in personalized
orange Civic Center T-shirts.
Sugar Ray and Odell had their
faces greased under the
Protective helmets, so that
misplaced punches could do little

or no harm. Their training gloves
weighed 16 ounces apiece, a
half-pound heavier than the
gloves Sugar Ray would use
against Luis "The Bull" Vega.
The training gloves are heavier,
yet protective, like big pillows on
the fighters' hands. Sugar Ray
and Odell would spar for five
3-minute rounds. An announcer
was also present, who advised tbe
spectators between rounds to
buy their tickets, which cost up
to twenty bucks a seat.
I don't think I ever realized it
before, but a fighter's personality
comes through when he fights.
Odell Leonard, built like a small
George Foreman, was a clown in
the ring. He was dancing around
Sugar Ray and making amusing
gestures to the audience. Odell
was definitely heavier than his
cousin, though shorter, and his the training rounds, I could teL
fighting skills were considerably that Sugar Ray has great
less developed than those of his potential He seemed loose, and

showed the determination that the crowd was treated to the fine
won him the gold medal in form that won Sugar Ray
Montreal. He is not, however, an recognition in the Olympics.

As a sparring partner, Odell was loudly after every round and to

and encouragement to Sugar Ray 'im sweat", and "put 'er in
throughout each round. Even in automatic, Odell", were flying

through the air. A few hecklers
were present, but in general the
crowd was jovial and any
heckling was ignored.
After the sparring was over,
Sugar Ray took time to sign
autographs and shake hands. He
was sincere in meeting and
talking to his admirers, which
undoubtedly accounts for his
great popularity. It was with
some difficulty that he made his
way to the heavy punching bag:
people especially youngsters.
were crowding around him. Sugar
Ray showed the same dynamic
style on the bag as he did in the
ring. Most of the crowd
remained, and gathered around
to watch. He attacked the bag for
about fifteen minutes and believe
me, he's no slouch. It was
extremely difficult not to be
impressed by his strength. While
Sugar Ray was punching his heart
out,Odell was skipping rope.
That may sound easy to some of
you, but it actually takes months
to learn to do it correctly,
involving precise timing and lots
of endurance. The only way
Floyd Patterson could learn to
do it was by jumping off the
boxing ring and bring the rope
over his head and under his feet
before he hit the floor. Sugar
Ray finished punching the bag
and after another session of
public relations, began skipping
rope. With this the training
session was ended.
The City of Baltimore is to be
congratulated for its efforts in
promoting Sugar Ray's fight. The
training session was well
organized; children and adults
were not discouraged from
climbing into the ring. Sugar Ray
was a perfect gentleman and the
trainers also took time to discuss
boxing with interested
spectators. Due to Baltimore's
support of Sugar Ray, I think his
career has been given a major
boost. From the appeal of a
freebie, more potential admierers
and supporters were exposed to
Sugar Ray than would have been
possible.
Since I watched Sugar Ray
train, he has had a very successful
bout (unanimous decision) with
Vega. The crowd was estimated
at over 9,000 people, outdoing

Muhammad Ali, who attracted
6,100 people to a Civic Center
exhibition fight in 1972. Sugar
Ray was very appreciative about
the attention he's received from
the City and in an interview on
Feb. 7 said, "Baltimore is the
home of Sugar Ray Leonard."
Manager Angelo Dundee alsc
must have been suitably
impressed, for he claims to have
Sugar Ray back for a fight in
Baltimore on April 2.
Does this interest in Sugar Ray
Leonard indicate a change in the
sport of boxing? In the past few
years, boxing has declined in
popularity, despite the attempts
of Ali and others to keep it in the
news. One of the reasons for the
rekindling of boxing may have
been the 1976 Olympics, where
the United States team won
about half the gold medals in
boxing. Sugar Ray was one of the
gold medalists and a favorite of
Howard Cosell. The sportscasters
agreed that of all the boxers at
Montreal, Sugar Ray had the best
chance to make it as a
professional. After he won the
gold medal, however, Sugar Ray
claimed he would not fight
professionally. Some thought he
made this statement because of a
problem with swelling hands.
Sugar Ray was questioned about
this in an interview before his
Civic Center fight and said that
iiis hands were in great shape. So
it seems that, regardless of his
statement at Montreal, Sugar Ray
is on his way to becoming a
successful pro boxer. It is a
well-known fact, however, that in
the boxing profession, the
heavyweights gather all the glory
and publicity. This near-axiom
might make Sugar Ray's path to
greater reknown a little
mcertain. His career is being
watched nationally, possibly
because aficionados feel he's the
one who can break the
heavyweight stranglehold on
boxing.
April 2
For those of you who missed
Sugar Ray, try to see him when
he returns April 2. Besides being
a native of Maryland, he's a fine
young athlete. Take it from a
novice boxing fan, you won't be
disappointed.

By ANDREW COHEN
The Blue Jay men's varsity
basketball team dropped into a
second place tie with Washington
College as they were completely
outplayed by the Widener
Pioneers Saturday night in
Chester, Pennsylvania, 62-47.
The game was so lopsided, in
fact, that if it hadn't been for
John Finston's game leading 26
points, the Jays could have gone
home at the end of the first half.
During the first 8 minutes,
however, the Blue Jays were very
much in the game. The Jays
controlled the opening tip, but
failed to connect when Dan
Kopcza's short turnaround jump
shot was blocked by 6'6"
forward Mark Tucker of Widener.
The Pioneers turned the
defensive gem into an offensive
surge capped off with a driving
layup from guard Mark Donahue,
who led the balanced scoring
attack for Widener with 19
points. Finston quickly tied the
game at 2 by pumping in a 25
foot jump shot from the top of
the foul circle.
Moments later, the Jays took
the lead when Andy Scheinfeld
hit a beautiful turn around jump
shot. After the score was tied,
Scheinfeld again put the Jays up
by driving past two Widener
defenders and scopping the ball
in. But two Widener buckets
dropped in by Donahue put the
Pioneers in the lead to stay 8-6.

The Jays hung close to the
Pioneers with two jump shots
from Randy Lovallo and two
foul shots sunk by Dean Uhler.
Widener then went on a scoring
binge, outscoring the Jays 8-2 in
the next three minutes. The Jays
went dry in the remaining 9
minutes of the first half,
mustering only two field goals
from Finston and Lovallo.
Costly turnovers and failure to
gain the offensive rebound
spelled the difference for the
Jays as they ended the first half
trailing 29-18. The Blue Jays shot
a poor 8-21 or 38% from the
floor while the Pioneers hit 13 of
31 or 47% of their shots. In
addition, the Jays were unable to
pull down one offensive rebound
in the first half.
The second half offered no
consolation to the visiting team
as the Pioneers ran the score to
34-18 before the Jays could
answer with a bucket from
Finston. The Widener team took
the opening tip and converted an
easy layup. Seconds later,
pioneer senior Jim Fitzpatrick
took a pinpoint pass from 6'6"
senior Dennis James and drove to
the hoop dropping in the shot. In
the process he was fouled,
allowing him to complete a three
point play.
An interesting call by the
referee prevented Widener from
taking an eighteen point lead.
Donahue led a Pioneer three on

one drive to the bucket and the
Widener guard eventually shot a
running layup. The ball bounced
around the rim for a while before
the Pioneer center (James)leaped
up and grabbed the ball, slammed
it into the hoop, and hung on the
rim. Hanging on the rim
constitutes a technical foul in
NCAA play. The referee also
called offensive goal tending,
explaining that the ball was
above the imaginery plane of the
basket when James took hold of
it. Unfortunately for the Jays,
technical free throw shooter
Kevin Kabat missed the shot.
The Pioneers continued to
pump the ball through the net,
but Finston seemed to answer
with his baseline jump shots
every time. At 12:43 of the
second half, guard Lovallo
sprained his ankle in the process
of attempting to block a shot.
The valuable 6'1" playmaker
took a flying leap at a Widener
offensive player and came up
limping. He was quickly replaced
with Duey Levine by Coach
Rupert.
"Randy is definitely going to
miss Monday and Wednesday
nights' games," commented
Coach Rupert. "Luckily the
x-rays taken came out negative."
The Blue Jays now stand at
5-3 in their league, tied with
Washington College. The next
two league games against
Haver ford College and

Swimmers kick booty, raise record to 9-2
The members of the Blue Jay
men's varsity swimming team
don't seem to care which
Division their opponents come
from—they've gotten into the
habit of beating everyone.
On February 5th, JHU racked
up its fifth win in seven decision
against Division I foes as the Jays
defeated American University
69-43. Hopkins raised its dual
meet record to 9-2 on February
12th when it stomped perennial
Division III powerhouse
Allegheny College, 72-41.
The competition against

The victory over Allegheny
was one of the season's biggest
wins. Not only is Allegheny a
serious contender for the
Division III championship that
has just eluded the grasp of JHU
the past two years, but the
Pennsylvanians had also beaten
defending champion St.
Lawrence earlier this year and
this meet could let the Jays see
how they rate against their main
opposition.
Repeating their method of the
previous week, Hopkins built up
a huge lead through the first
three events and never looked
back. Following a Hopkins win in
the opening relay, JHU freshman
sensation Tim Collins continued
his excellence in the distance
freestyle events by taking first
place in the 1650-yard freestyle

Smiddy and Collins were double
victors, but it was some other
swimmers who garnered the
Coach's praise.
Frank McGovern, Brian
Kutsunai, Eric Horning, John
Dierkes and Brad Procton were
all noted for their outstanding
efforts. In addition to performing
well against Allegheny, each of
these swimmers has now
qualified for the NCAA
championships, bringing the

Hopkins delegation to date to 11
swimmers and 3 divers.
The Jays next meet is
tomorrow night in College Park
when they take on rival
Maryland. The Jays have never
beaten the Terrapins and are
looking to break that dubious
streak. The final home meet of
the year is next Tuesday when
JHU will entertain MAC-rival
Dickinson.
